Sickle cell anemia is a genetic disorder that affects the red blood cells, causing them to take on a sickle shape instead of their normal round structure. In this condition, some of the oxygen-carrying hemoglobin molecules get distorted and form abnormal hemoglobin S (HbS) rather than regular hemoglobin A (HbA). This abnormal HbS causes the red blood cells to become rigid and sticky.

When people inherit one copy of the HBB gene with a mutation for sickle cell anemia from each parent, they have two copies of genes carrying mutated instructions for producing HbS. As a result, these individuals develop sickle cell anemia.

Some common symptoms that indicate someone may have sickle cell anemia include:

1. Anemia: Shortage of healthy red blood cells can lead to fatigue, weakness, and paleness due to reduced oxygen supply.
2. Frequent infections: As sickle-shaped red blood cells damage spleen function making it less able to filter bacteria effectively.
3. Pain episodes (also called "pain crises"): Occur when clumped together sickled RBCs block blood flow in small vessels leading sudden pain through various parts body
4 .Swelling in hands or feet: Blocked blood flow leads fluid accumulation extremities known as dactylitis affecting infants toddlers primarily 
5.Jaundice eye whites &skin turns yellowish due rapid breakdown haemoglobins processed liver excreted bile which accumulates system if not cleared rapidly enough
